articles.headline: Clarissa Ward of CNN Looks Back on the Afghanistan War
articles.snippet: The network’s chief international correspondent, one of the most visible reporters during the withdrawal of U.S. troops, decided to become a reporter after an epiphany on 9/11.
articles.abstract: The network’s chief international correspondent, one of the most visible reporters during the withdrawal of U.S. troops, decided to become a reporter after an epiphany on 9/11.
articles.lead_paragraph: Clarissa Ward had four days to catch up on sleep and see her two sons, ages 1 and 3, at her parents’ home in France. Then she was off again, back to work, making her way through Qatar to Pakistan, where she reported from the Afghanistan border.

articles.headline: The Masked Professor vs. the Unmasked Student
articles.snippet: At universities, some instructors are finding the return to the classroom a nerve-racking experience. A few have quit — one in the middle of class.
articles.abstract: At universities, some instructors are finding the return to the classroom a nerve-racking experience. A few have quit — one in the middle of class.
articles.lead_paragraph: Matthew Boedy, an associate professor of rhetoric and composition, sent out a raw emotional appeal to his students at the University of North Georgia just before classes began: The Covid-19 Delta variant was rampaging through the state, filling up hospital beds. He would teach class in the equivalent of full body armor — vaccinated and masked.

articles.headline: Warning of Income Gap, Xi Tells China’s Tycoons to Share Wealth
articles.snippet: As the country’s leader prepares for a likely third term, he is promising “common prosperity” to lift farmers and working families into the middle class.
articles.abstract: As the country’s leader prepares for a likely third term, he is promising “common prosperity” to lift farmers and working families into the middle class.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four decades ago, Deng Xiaoping declared that China would “let some people get rich first” in its race for growth. Now, Xi Jinping has put China’s tycoons on notice that it is time for them to share more wealth with the rest of the country.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley, Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: The Missing Piece in the Push for Boardroom Diversity
articles.snippet: Private companies are lagging behind publicly traded firms, but don’t receive the same scrutiny.
articles.abstract: Private companies are lagging behind publicly traded firms, but don’t receive the same scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, major public companies across the country pledged to increase diversity in their boardrooms, one of the actions taken after the murder of George Floyd in police custody. Corporate directors set goals, and some have begun to make progress, with investors, activists and others tracking their commitments on racial equity.

articles.headline: In Silicon Valley, Criminal Prosecutors See No Evil
articles.snippet: The Elizabeth Holmes fraud trial is set to be a major spectacle, but tech executives generally get a pass when it comes to wrongdoing.
articles.abstract: The Elizabeth Holmes fraud trial is set to be a major spectacle, but tech executives generally get a pass when it comes to wrongdoing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The coronavirus pandemic has helped Silicon Valley companies in many ways, from bringing them hordes of new customers to weakening the competition to juicing the bottom line.

articles.headline: Latinos Shape California. Why Are So Many Sitting Out the Recall?
articles.snippet: As Gov. Gavin Newsom faces a recall election, he has struggled to connect with Hispanic voters, who make up nearly a third of the electorate.
articles.abstract: As Gov. Gavin Newsom faces a recall election, he has struggled to connect with Hispanic voters, who make up nearly a third of the electorate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the California Recall Election and Governor Newsom.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Jill Cowan

articles.headline: Biden’s Electric Car Plans Hinge on Having Enough Chargers
articles.snippet: The United States has about 100,000 public chargers, far fewer than Europe and China. It needs 10 times as many, auto experts say, to complete the switch from combustion engine vehicles.
articles.abstract: The United States has about 100,000 public chargers, far fewer than Europe and China. It needs 10 times as many, auto experts say, to complete the switch from combustion engine vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: In President Biden’s vision of a green future, half of all new cars sold in 2030 will be electric. But something really basic is standing in the way of that plan: enough outlets to plug in all those cars and trucks.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi, Matthew Goldstein and Erin Woo

articles.headline: Taliban Appoint Stalwarts to Top Government Posts
articles.snippet: The Taliban’s violent response to the latest demonstration, which included hundreds of women in Kabul, was another sign that they will not tolerate peaceful dissent in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The Taliban’s violent response to the latest demonstration, which included hundreds of women in Kabul, was another sign that they will not tolerate peaceful dissent in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban announced a caretaker government on Tuesday, taking a major step in re-establishing their Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan, and empowering many of the movement’s stalwarts from their regime in the 1990s.
articles.byline: By Matthieu Aikins and Jim Huylebroek
